Here, the Buddha says:

Because one attains the dharma nature, one knows that the eighteen natures such as form are all the dharma nature.
As for the characteristics of the dharma nature, the Buddha says:
Without distinction, without non-distinction.
Without distinction means that one cannot point to this or that, without discrimination, without characteristics, and without measure;
Without non-distinction means not clinging to the characteristics of the destruction of non-characteristics, non-measures, etc.
The dharma nature is not seen because of two obstacles:
First, having characteristics and having measure; second, being without characteristics and without measure.

Having characteristics and having measure is coarse, being without characteristics and without measure is subtle, therefore it is said that the characteristics of the dharma nature are without distinction and without non-distinction.

When bodhisattvas enter the three gates of liberation and abide in the three true dharmas such as suchness, they are then able to contemplate and know the general and specific characteristics of all dharmas.
